docs.lead_paragraph: The WebMD Corporation, an Internet health information company that has lost more than $2 billion, will take a $275 million charge in the fourth quarter to end two ventures with Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation. The News Corporation will take back WebMD's 50 percent stake in the Health Network cable channel, drop plans to promote WebMD overseas and reduce advertising and promotion services for the Internet company to $205 million over 10 years from $700 million. WebMD, which links doctors, patients and health insurers on the Internet, will cancel plans to issue 8.3 million shares to the News Corporation. WebMD is scaling back its consumer-health Web site to focus on providing software and electronic processing of health insurance claims.

docs.lead_paragraph: A front-page article on Monday about increased insurance coverage for mental health care referred incorrectly to the nine million people who will benefit from changes in the program for federal employees. Almost three million are current employees; the others are dependents and retirees.

docs.lead_paragraph: Ann Smith of Lindenhurst, N.Y., who retired recently from Lucent Technologies, wants to continue using a health maintenance organization, but her choices will be limited. This week, most of the H.M.O.'s that had served Medicare recipients living in Suffolk County are discontinuing services to them. She could opt for traditional coverage through Medicare, the federal health insurance program for disabled people and those 65 and older, she said. But Medicare does not pay for the medicine she relies on to control high blood pressure, a benefit the H.M.O. had offered.

headline.main: Suffolk Elderly Feel the Loss of H.M.O.'s Drug Coverage

docs.abstract: Article discusses plight of many Medicare recipients in Suffolk County, NY, whose coverage is being discontinued by most health maintenance organizations; HMO's discontinued services to county's Medicare population because Federal reimbursement rates are lower than those in New York City even though health care costs are comparable; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: American consumers lost little last week when the Clinton administration scuttled a drug-import bill passed with much fanfare last year by a Congress facing an election. The bill was intended to curb the rapidly rising costs of prescription drugs to patients and health insurers by allowing Americans to buy American-made medications at the lower, regulated prices found abroad. In the hunt for affordable prescription drugs, that bill was a toothless tiger. True, drugmakers charge more in America, lowering the price tag for foreign customers that resist higher prices. But this ''price discrimination,'' as economists call it, is a common one in industries that have high fixed costs but marginal production costs. For pharmaceutical companies, research and development costs are high, but the cost of making the pills are relatively low. That's why they can sell their products at cut-rate prices to foreign buyers, who otherwise could not afford them.

headline.main: How to Lower The Cost of Drugs

docs.abstract: Prof Uwe E Reinhadrt Op-Ed article opposes bill to allow Americans to buy American-made medications at the lower, regulated prices found abroad and says proper response to such price discrimination is fund independent, nonprofit research into whether 'new, improved' drugs are indeed significantly new and improved; says rising drug prices are driven by a growing stream of new, 'mee-too' medications that typically cost twice or three times as much as the drugs they replace (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: New York City schools now offer so many services that on a typical morning at Intermediate School 143 in Washington Heights, Wilbin Heredia, 11, might be studying math in Room 229 or having his teeth checked in Room 114. Wilbin, a sixth grader, was recently in a sea-green dentist's chair under a photograph of kittens. He opened his mouth as Dr. Marlene Navedo poked around, asking him who put in his braces, whether his gums bled at night and whether he had his own toothbrush at home. Wilbin does have his own toothbrush. But ''a lot of the kids share,'' Dr. Navedo explained as she peered at Wilbin's back molars. ''One toothbrush for two or three kids.''

headline.main: Getting Homework Checked (and Teeth, as Well)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Clinton administration released projections last week showing that the estimated federal surplus will hit $5 trillion over the next 10 years, almost $1 trillion more than previously expected. Supporters of President-elect George W. Bush say that the bigger surplus now expected will provide the wherewithal to pass Mr. Bush's proposed $1.9 trillion tax cut, which the Bush team believes is needed to spur an economy that is slowing down. But a careful look at the numbers shows that the Bush plan remains a bad fiscal idea. Start with the fact that $2.5 trillion of the projected surplus comes from Social Security and another $500 billion or so comes from Medicare. Both pots of money are essentially off limits. Congress appears committed to using the extra money from these programs to pay down the federal debt -- a use that does not affect the solvency of either program but does improve the overall health of the future economy. So that leaves only about $2 trillion of the projected $5 trillion surplus for tax cuts and new government spending.

headline.main: The Surplus and the Tax Cut

docs.abstract: Editorial says Pres-elect George W Bush's proposed $1.9 trillion tax cut remains bad fiscal idea, despite recent projections by Clinton administration showing estimated federal surplus will hit $5 trillion over next 10 years, almost $1 trillion more than previously expected; says plan is wrong economic elixir, but that smaller, targeted tax cut could indeed make sense (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK BRONX: PREGNANT WOMAN KILLED A 23-year-old pregnant woman was killed in an apartment early yesterday morning, the police said. The woman, Shari Scurry, was shot in the head in the bathroom of an apartment at 15 Marcy Place in Mount Eden. Sgt. Victor Ramos, a police spokesman, said several people in the apartment at the time of the shooting were being questioned last night. He said Ms. Scurry lived at 355 East 184th Street in the Bronx. David Rohde (NYT) BROOKLYN: FIRST POLICE SHOOTING OF NEW YEAR Two officers wounded a 17-year-old boy early yesterday morning after he pointed a gun at them, the police said, in the first police shooting this year. The boy, Frasier Lavel, was shot in the shoulder and stomach and was in stable condition last night at Kings County Hospital Center. Sgt. Victor Ramos, a police spokesman, said two officers responded at 12:01 a.m. to a report of gunshots at 880 St. Marks Avenue in Crown Heights. When they arrived, they saw two young men firing handguns and pursued them. One of them, Mr. Lavel, pointed his gun at them and they both fired several shots at him, Sergeant Ramos said. The other young man was not apprehended. David Rohde (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: Where will the stock market go in 2001? Will technology stocks rebound? Is a recession likely? To ponder these questions, we gathered three of the best thinkers in the financial markets, two who offer advice from New York and one who manages money from Minnesota. Douglas Cliggott, the United States equity strategist at J. P. Morgan, who correctly forecast that the Standard & Poor's 500 would end 2000 at about 1,300, down from 1,469.25 at the close of 1999, is cautious again this year. So is James W. Paulsen, the chief investment officer of Wells Capital Management, a money management firm in Minneapolis, and a man who has often picked up changes in the economy and markets before they become conventional wisdom. But Chris Callies, the top American strategist for Merrill Lynch, who a year ago was correctly warning that tighter monetary policy could hurt stock prices early in the year but hoped for a rebound later in 2000, argues that pessimism is way overdone and has confidence that the Federal Reserve will deal with the economy as well as it has in previous years.

headline.main: Making Sense of the Moves in the Markets

docs.abstract: Direction of stock market in 2001 is discussed by Merrill Lynch analyst Chris Callies, Wells Capital Management chief investment officer James W Paulsen and Douglas Cliggott, US equity strategist at J P Morgan; chart; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The emphasis on Social Security in the presidential campaign reflected the growing awareness that in only a decade or so, millions of baby boomers are going to give America a greatly increased population over 65. Few seem to recognize, however, that unprecedented rates of longevity and a coming revolution in health treatments mean this group of older Americans will not only be larger, but will live longer, than those before. It's disturbing that the scope of our discussion about dealing with what's coming is truncated, as though we need only nibble around the edges -- say, by deciding whether retirement should occur at 65 or 67 or how prescription drugs should be provided. There is another conversation to be had: one concerning the optimal design of a new stage in life.

headline.main: On the Brink of a Brand-New Old Age

docs.abstract: Laura L Carstensen Op-Ed article says emphasis on Social Security in presidential campaign reflected growing awareness that in only decade or so, millions of baby boomers are going to give America greatly increased population over 65, but that few seem to recognize that unprecedented rates of longevity and coming revolution in health treatments mean group of older Americans will not only be larger, but will live longer than those before; says national conversation about aging must expand beyond discussing how to care for graying population; drawing (M)
